{{Orphan|date=November 2013}}
The '''Nadal formula''', also called '''Nadal's formula''', is an equation in [[railway]] design that relates the downward force exerted by a [[train]]'s wheels upon the rail, with the lateral force of the wheel's flange against the face of the rail. This relationship is significant in railway design, as a [[Derailment#Slow speed derailments|wheel-climb derailment]] may occur if the lateral and vertical forces are not properly considered.<ref name=APTA>[http://www.aptastandards.com/portals/0/press_pdfs/Mechanical/SS-M-015-06%20Wheel%20Flange%20Angle.pdf APTA SS-M-015-06 Standard for wheel flange angle for passenger equipment]</ref>
The Nadal formula is represented by: <math>\left(\frac{L}{V}\right){{=}}\left(\frac{\tan(\delta)-\mu}{1+\mu*\tan(\delta)}\right)</math>
In this equation, L and V refer to the lateral and vertical forces acting upon the rail and wheel, δ is the angle made when the wheel flange is in contact with the rail face, and μ is the coefficient of friction between the wheel and the rail.<ref name=APTA />
Typically, the [[axle load]] for a railway vehicle should be such that the lateral forces of the wheel against the rail should not exceed 50% of the vertical down-force of the vehicle on the rail.<ref name=DOT>[http://www.fra.dot.gov/downloads/Counsel/nprm/tssnprm.pdf Federal Register, July 3, 1997]</ref> Put another way, there should be twice as much downward force holding the wheel to the rail, as there is lateral force which will tend to cause the wheel to climb in turns. This ratio is accomplished by matching the [[Wheelset (rail transport)|wheelset]] with the appropriate [[rail profile]] to achieve the L/V ratio desired. If the L/V ratio gets too high, the wheel flange will be pressing against the rail face, and during a turn this will cause the wheel to climb the face of the rail, potentially derailing the railcar.
==Wagner Formula==
The Nadal formula assumes the wheel remains perpendicular to the rail—it does not take into account [[hunting oscillation]] of the wheelset, or the movement of the wheel flange contact point against the rail.<ref name="Dukkipati">{{cite book | last=Dukkipati | first=Rao | title=Vehicle Dynamics | publisher=Narosa Publishing House | year=2000 | isbn=978-81-7319-265-4 | pages=227–228}}</ref>
A variation of the Nadal formula, which does take these factors into consideration, is the Wagner formula. As the wheelset yaws relative to the rail, the vertical force V is no longer completely vertical, but is now acting at an angle to the vertical, β. When this angle is factored into the Nadal formula, the result is the Wagner formula:<ref name="Dukkipati" />
<math>\left(\frac{L}{V}\right){{=}}\left(\frac{\tan(\delta)-\mu*\cos\beta}{(1+\mu*\tan(\delta))*\cos\beta)}\right)</math>
When the vertical force is truly vertical (that is, β=0 and therefore cos(β)=1), the Wagner formula equals the Nadal formula.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Applied sciences]] [[Category:Train wheels]] [[Category:Rail technologies]]

revision.comment: /* Description */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Indian journal of ophthalmology → Indian Journal of Ophthalmology
revision.text:
'''Neuro-ophthalmology''' is an academically-oriented [[subspecialty]] that merges the fields of [[neurology]] and [[ophthalmology]], often dealing with complex systemic diseases that have manifestations in the [[visual system]]. Neuro-ophthalmologists initially complete a residency in either neurology, neurosurgery, or ophthalmology, then do a [[Fellowship (medicine)|fellowship]] in the complementary field. Since diagnostic studies can be normal in patients with significant neuro-ophthalmic disease,<ref name=Lessell>{{cite journal|last1=Lessell|first1=S|title=What can we expect in neuro-ophthalmology in the next century?|journal=Archives of Ophthalmology|date=Apr 2000|volume=118|issue=4|pages=553–4|pmid=10766142|doi=10.1001/archopht.118.4.553}}</ref> a detailed [[medical history]] and [[physical exam]] is essential, and neuro-ophthalmologists often spend a significant amount of time with their patients.
Common pathology referred to a neuro-ophthalmologist includes afferent visual system disorders (e.g. [[optic neuritis]], [[optic neuropathy]], [[papilledema]], [[brain tumor]]s or [[stroke]]s) and efferent visual system disorders (e.g. [[anisocoria]], [[diplopia]], [[ophthalmoplegia]], [[ptosis (eyelid)|ptosis]], [[nystagmus]], [[blepharospasm]], [[seizures]] of the eye or eye muscles, and [[hemifacial spasm]]). The largest international society of neuro-ophthalmologists is the North American Neuro-Ophthalmological Society (NANOS),<ref>{{cite web|title=North American Neuro-Ophthalmology Society|url=http://www.nanosweb.org/home.cfm|website=North American Neuro-Ophthalmology Society Home Page|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref> which organizes an annual meeting and publishes the Journal of Neuro-Ophthalmology. Neuro-ophthalmologists are often faculty at large [[Academic health science centre|university-based medical centers]]. Patients often have co-existing disease in other fields ([[rheumatology]], [[endocrinology]], [[oncology]], [[cardiology]], etc.), thus the neuro-ophthalmologist is often a liaison between the [[ophthalmology]] department and other departments in the medical center.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McDonnell|first1=Peter|title=Is neuro-ophthalmology in jeopardy?|journal=Ophthalmology Times|date=1 Nov 2004|volume=29|issue=21|page=4|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/15025751/neuro-ophthalmology-jeopardy}}</ref>
==Description== Neuro-ophthalmology focuses on diseases of the nervous system that affect vision, control of [[eye movement]]s, or [[pupillary reflex]]es. Neuro-ophthalmologists often see patients with complex multi-system disease and “[[Zebra (medicine)|zebras]]” are not uncommon. Neuro-ophthalmologists are often active teachers in their academic institution, and the first four winners of the prestigious Straatsma [[American Academy of Ophthalmology]] teaching awards were neuro-ophthalmologists.<ref name=Frohman>{{cite journal|last1=Frohman|first1=LP|title=The human resource crisis in neuro-ophthalmology.|journal=Journal of Neuro-Ophthalmology|date=Sep 2008|volume=28|issue=3|pages=231–4|pmid=18769291|doi=10.1097/wno.0b013e318185e084}}</ref> Neuro-ophthalmology is mostly non-procedural, however, neuro-ophthalmologists may be trained to perform [[Strabismus surgery|eye muscle surgery]] to treat adult [[strabismus]], optic nerve fenestration for [[idiopathic intracranial hypertension]], and [[botulinum toxin|botulinum]] injections for [[blepharospasm]] or [[hemifacial spasm]].
Two neuro-ophthalmology fellows of Andrew G. Lee published reasons why they chose to pursue the discipline:<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Spitze|first1=A|last2=Al-Zubidi|first2=N|last3=Lam|first3=P|last4=Yalamanchili|first4=S|last5=Lee|first5=AG|title=Neuro-ophthalmology as a career.|journal=Indian Journal of Ophthalmology|date=October 2014|volume=62|issue=10|pages=1013–4|pmid=25449937|doi=10.4103/0301-4738.146007|pmc=4278112}}</ref> {{quotation|"The neuro-ophthalmologist is often the sub-specialty that others turn to when the etiology of visual decline is in question. They are often uniquely suited to provide a global and comprehensive perspective to any complex medical, neurologic, ophthalmologic, or neurosurgical case. A neuro-ophthalmology patient has often already seen 2, if not 3 or more other specialists by the time they arrive at our door. We particularly enjoy the sense of satisfaction, medical accomplishment, and difference we can make in patient's lives when able to discover a diagnosis and treat the condition.
What makes the neuro-ophthalmologist unique is the global viewpoint of the integration and interaction of complex and systemic disorders on visual function. There is no “routine day” for us in neuro-ophthalmology clinic as there is always an interesting patient from which we can learn. Any day can hold a combination of corneal, retinal, optic nerve, rheumatologic, neurologic, infectious, or neurosurgical variety."}}
==Historical Developments== At the turn of the 20th Century, there was no textbook in the English language on neuro-ophthalmology. In 1906, Dr. William Campbell Posey, Professor of Ophthalmology in the Philadelphia Polyclinic and Dr. William G. Spiller, Professor of Neurology in the University of Pennsylvania, edited ''The Eye and Nervous System: Their Diagnostic Relations By Various Authors'' [[J.B. Lippincott & Co.]]. According to the Preface to this book, "Although it is generally conceded that a knowledge of neurology is indispensable to the ophthalmologist and that an acquaintanceship with ophthalmology is of the greatest service to the neurologist, there is no book in the English language which covers the ground where the two specialties meet."<ref>{{Cite book|last=Posey|first=William Campbell|last2=Spiller|first2=William G.|title=The Eye and Nervous System: Their Diagnostic Relations by Various Authors|location=Philadelphia and London|publisher=J.B. Lippincott Company|year=1906}}</ref>
[[Frank B. Walsh]] was a pioneer of neuro-ophthalmology, helping to popularize and develop the field. Walsh was born in [[Oxbow, Saskatchewan]] in 1895 and earned a degree from University of Manitoba in 1921. He joined the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute at [[Johns Hopkins University]] and began organizing Saturday morning neuro-ophthalmology conferences. Walsh compiled the first neuro-ophthalmology textbook, which was published in 1947 and has been updated over the years by generations of his students.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Angelucci|first1=Diane|title=Groundbreaking neuro-ophthalmologist honored|url=http://www.eyeworld.org/article.php?sid=1115&strict=0&morphologic=0&query=|website=EyeWorld|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref>
==Future== Doctors have been decreasing the time spent with a patient due to economic pressures, the use of [[Mid-level practitioner|nonphysicians]], and increasing reliance on [[medical laboratory|laboratory tests]]. Neuro-ophthalmology has been affected more so than other specialties due to the complexity of the patients and the time required to do a neuro-ophthalmic history and physical exam.<ref name= Frohman /> Additionally, the current [[Fee-for-service|medical reimbursement system]] rewards quantity of service (performing assembly line procedures) rather than quality of service (making a correct diagnosis, patient education, and counseling), and seeing complex patients is not adequately recognized.
Improved [[functional neuroimaging]] is paving the way for better understanding, assessment, and management of many neurologic and neuro-ophthalmologic conditions. As our understanding of [[neuroscience]] evolves, neuro-ophthalmologists are becoming increasingly better at treatment, rather than only [[Medical diagnosis|diagnosis]], and novel therapies are emerging to treat traditionally vision-devastating disease.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Newman|first1=SA|title=Interventional neuro-ophthalmology: not an oxymoron.|journal=Journal of Neuro-Ophthalmology|date=Jun 2012|volume=32|issue=2|pages=177–84|pmid=22617746|doi=10.1097/wno.0b013e318256638e}}</ref> For example, clinical trials began in February 2014 to use [[gene therapy]] to treat [[Leber hereditary optic neuropathy]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lam|first1=BL|last2=Feuer|first2=WJ|last3=Schiffman|first3=JC|last4=Porciatti|first4=V|last5=Vandenbroucke|first5=R|last6=Rosa|first6=PR|last7=Gregori|first7=G|last8=Guy|first8=J|title=Trial end points and natural history in patients with G11778A Leber hereditary optic neuropathy : preparation for gene therapy clinical trial.|journal=JAMA Ophthalmology|date=Apr 1, 2014|volume=132|issue=4|pages=428–36|pmid=24525545|doi=10.1001/jamaophthalmol.2013.7971|pmc=4266137}}</ref> which is one of the first uses of [[gene therapy]] in the [[central nervous system]]. Progress has also been made in understanding [[retinal ganglion cell]] regeneration and in re-establishing [[synapse|synaptic connections]] from the [[optic nerve]] to the [[brain]],<ref name=Lessell /> more than in other regions of the [[central nervous system]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Watanabe|first1=M|last2=Fukuda|first2=Y|title=Survival and axonal regeneration of retinal ganglion cells in adult cats.|journal=Progress in retinal and eye research|date=Nov 2002|volume=21|issue=6|pages=529–53|pmid=12433376|doi=10.1016/s1350-9462(02)00037-x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Xia|first1=Y|last2=Nawy|first2=S|last3=Carroll|first3=RC|title=Activity-dependent synaptic plasticity in retinal ganglion cells.|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|date=Nov 7, 2007|volume=27|issue=45|pages=12221–9|pmid=17989288|doi=10.1523/jneurosci.2086-07.2007|pmc=3073613}}</ref> One of the goals of the [[National Institutes of Health]] is to use the [[visual system]] as a window to understand [[neuroplasticity|neural plasticity]] and [[regenerative medicine]] in the [[central nervous system]],<ref>{{cite web|title=NEI Audacious Goal Initiative|url=http://www.nei.nih.gov/audacious/|website=National Eye Institute|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref> an area of [[neuroscience]] that has a promising future and is intimately intertwined with neuro-ophthalmology.
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://library.med.utah.edu/NOVEL/ The Neuro-Ophthalmology Virtual Education Library] (NOVEL)
{{Neuroscience}}
[[Category:Neuroscience]] [[Category:Ophthalmology]] [[Category:Neurology]]

revision.text:
'''Public history''' is a broad range of activities undertaken by people with some training in the discipline of [[history]] who are generally working outside of specialized academic settings. Public history practice is deeply rooted in the areas of [[historic preservation]], [[archival science]], [[oral history]], museum [[curator]]ship, and other related fields. The field has become increasingly professionalized in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] since the late 1970s. Some of the most common settings for the practice of public history are [[museums]], historic homes and [[historic site]]s, parks, battlefields, [[archives]], film and television companies, and all levels of government.
==Definition== Because it incorporates a wide range of practices and takes place in many different settings, public history proves resistant to being precisely defined. Four key elements often emerge from the discourse of those who identify themselves as public historians: * use of the methods of the historical discipline * an emphasis on the usefulness of historical knowledge in some way that goes beyond purely academic or [[antiquarian]] purposes * an emphasis on professional training and practice * an aim to deepen and empower public connection with the past
These elements are expressed in the 1989 mission statement of the U.S.-based [[National Council on Public History]]: "To promote the utility of history in social through professional practice.".<ref>[http://www.ncph.org/Portals/13/About%20the%20Council/NCPHsFirstDecade.pdf Reflections on an Idea: NCPH’s First Decade]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by Barbara J. Howe, Chair's Annual Address, The Public Historian, Vol. 11, No. 3 (Summer 1989), pp. 69–85</ref> They are also present in a definition drafted by the NCPH board in 2007, stating, "Public history is a movement, methodology, and approach that promotes the collaborative study and practice of history; its practitioners embrace a mission to make their special insights accessible and useful to the public." However, this draft definition prompted some challenges on the H-Public listserv from people in the field,<ref>"[http://www.ncph.org/WhatisPublicHistory/tabid/282/language/en-US/Default.aspx "Public History Redux"]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Public History News'' (September 2007)</ref> who raised questions about whether public history is solely an endeavor by professional or trained historians, or if [[shared historical authority]] should be a key element of the field. Others have pointed out that the existence of many "publics" for public history complicates the task of definition. For example, historian [[Peter Novick]] has questioned whether much of what is termed public history should actually be called ''private'' history (for example, the creation of corporate histories or archives) or ''popular'' history (for example, research or exhibits conducted outside the norms of the historical discipline).<ref>Peter Novick, ''That Noble Dream: The "Objectivity Question" and the American Historical Profession'' (1988), 510-21</ref> Cathy Stanton has also identified a more radical element in North American public history but has asked: 'how much room is there for the progressive component in the public history movement?'<ref>Cathy Stanton, '' The Lowell Experiment: Public History in a Postindustrial City'' (U. of Massachusetts Press, 2006), p. 28</ref> [[Hilda Kean]] and Paul Ashton have also discussed the differences in public history in Britain, Australia, New Zealand and the U.S., arguing against 'a rigid demarcation between "historians" and "their publics"'.<ref>Paul Ashton and Hilda Kean (eds), ''People and their Pasts: Public History Today'' (Palgrave Macmillan, 2009), p. 1</ref> A 2008 survey of almost 4,000 practitioners predominantly in the U.S. showed that a substantial proportion (almost one quarter of respondents) expressed some reservations about the term and whether it applied to their own work.<ref>John Dichtl and Robert B. Townsend, [http://www.historians.org/Perspectives/issues/2009/0909/0909pub1.cfm "A Picture of Public History]: Preliminary Results from the 2008 Survey of Public History Professionals" in ''Public History News'', Vol. 29, No. 4 (September 2009)</ref>
In general, those who embrace the term ''public historian'' accept that the boundaries of the field are flexible. Its definition remains a work in progress, subject to continual re-evaluation of practitioners' relationships with different audiences, goals, and political, economic, or cultural settings.
==Related fields==
Public history refers to a wide variety of professional and academic fields.<ref>[https://public-history-weekly.degruyter.com/3-2015-2/public-history-sublation-german-debate/ Marko Demantowsky, ''“Public History” – Sublation of a German Debate?'', Public History Weekly, volume 3, number 2, 2015]</ref> Some of these include: * [[Applied history]] * [[Archival science]] * [[Cultural Heritage Management]] * [[Digital History]] * [[Heritage Interpretation]] * [[Historic Preservation]] * [[Historical archaeology]] * [[Museology]] * [[Oral History]] * [[Public humanities]]
In addition, a sub-field of scholarly study has developed over the past several decades which focuses on the history and theory of collective memory and history-making. This body of scholarship (typified by the winners of the National Council on Public History Book Award) may also be considered to be "public history."
==History==
Public history has many antecedents. These include [[Museum#History museums|history museums]], [[Historical society|historical societies]], public and private [[archive]]s and collections, hereditary and memorial associations, [[Historic preservation|preservation organizations]], historical and heritage projects and offices within government agencies, and depictions of history in popular culture of all kinds (for example, [[historical fiction]]). Ludmilla Jordanova has also observed that 'the state... lies at the heart of public history', linking public history to the rise of the nation state.<ref>Ludmilla Jordanova, ''The Practice of History'' (London: Edward Arnold, 2003) p. 155.</ref> (English Theologian William Paley declared in 1794 that 'public history' was a 'register of the successes and disappointments... and the quarrels of those who engage in contentions [for] power'.)<ref>Editorial, ''Public History Review'', vol 10, 2003, p. 5.</ref> In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a distinct historical discipline formed within Western universities, and this had the effect of gradually separating scholars who practiced history professionally from amateur or public practitioners.<ref>Ian Tyrrell, ''Historians in Public: the Practice of American History, 1890-1970'' (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2005), p. 209.</ref> While there continued to be trained historians working in public settings, there was a general retreat from public engagement among professional historians by the middle decades of the twentieth century.<ref>Rebecca Conard, ''Benjamin Shambaugh and the Intellectual Foundations of Public History'' (Iowa City: University of Iowa Press, 2002), p. 148</ref>
During the 1970s, a number of political, economic, social, and historiographical developments worked to reverse this trend, converging to produce a new field that explicitly identified itself as “public history”. The social justice movements of the 1960s and 1970s had sparked an interest in the histories of non-dominant people and groups—for example, women, working-class people, ethnic and racial minorities—rather than the [[Great man theory|“great men”]] who had traditionally been the focus of many historical narratives. In Britain, this emerged through the History Workshop Movement. Many historians embraced [[social history]] as a subject, and some were eager to become involved in public projects as a way of using their scholarship in activist or public-oriented ways.<ref>James Green, ''Taking History to Heart: The Power of the Past in Building Social Movements'' (Amherst, Massachusetts: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 2000), p. 2</ref> In the U.S., a severe shortage of academic jobs for historians led many to consider careers outside the academy.<ref>Novick, ''That Noble Dream'', p. 512</ref> At the same time, publicly funded efforts were underway in many Western countries, ranging from national celebrations like the [[United States Bicentennial]] to multiculturalist projects in [[Multiculturalism in Australia|Australia]] and [[Multiculturalism in Canada|Canada]], paralleled by widespread public interest in [[genealogy]], the tracing of folk and family [[Roots revival|“roots”]], and other history-related activities. In the wake of [[deindustrialization]] in many industrial places, governments also supported [[Urban renewal|regeneration or revitalization projects]] that increasingly included the use of local history and culture as an attraction or a basis for [[place branding|“re-branding”]] a depressed area.<ref>Bella Dicks, ''Culture on Display: The Production of Contemporary Visitability'' (Maidenhead, UK: Open University Press, 2003), p. 35</ref> Out of necessity, inclination, or both, a growing number of people with graduate training in history found employment in these kinds of non-academic settings. Public policy decisions like the passage of the U.S. [[National Historic Preservation Act of 1966]] and the Canadian government's addition of “historical researcher” as a civil service category in the 1970s,<ref>John R. English, "The Tradition of Public History in Canada," ''The Public Historian'' Vol. 5, No. 1 (Winter 1983), pp. 58-59</ref> along with the rise of [[cultural tourism]] and the increasing professionalization of many museums and historical societies, have spurred the growth of the field.
In the U.S., the birth of the public history field can be traced to the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], where Robert Kelley, a member of the history faculty, obtained a [[Rockefeller Foundation]] grant in 1976 to create a graduate program to train young historians for public and private sector careers.<ref>G. Wesley Johnson, "The Origins of ''The Public Historian'' and the National Council on Public History," ''The Public Historian'' Vol. 21, No. 3 (Summer 1999), pp. 167-79</ref> Kelley drew on his own extensive experience as a consultant and legal witness in water litigation cases in conceiving the idea of “public history” as a field in its own right. Conferences in Scottsdale, Arizona in 1978 and Montecito, California in 1979 helped to catalyze the new field. The launch of a professional journal, ''[[The Public Historian]]'', in 1978, and the founding of the [[National Council on Public History]] in 1979 further served to give public-minded historians in the academy and isolated practitioners outside of it a sense that they shared a set of missions, experiences, and methods.
Public history in Canada has followed a similar trajectory in many ways, including the experience of an academic “jobs crisis” in the 1970s and the importance of government as a source of employment for public historians.<ref>English, "Tradition of Public History in Canada"</ref> In 1983, the University of Waterloo created a Masters program in Public History (now defunct), followed by The University of Western Ontario in 1986, and Carleton University in 2002. Also as in the U.S., Canadian public funding for history and heritage projects has shrunk in the past two decades, with public historians increasingly accountable to funders for the effectiveness of their work.<ref>Lyle Dick, "Public History in Canada: An Introduction," ''The Public Historian'' Vol. 31, No. 1 (February 2009), pp. 9-10</ref> Public history also exists as an identifiable field in Australia<ref>[[Ann Curthoys]] and Paula Hamilton, “What Makes History Public?” ''Public History Review'' 1992, pp. 8-13</ref> and to a lesser extent in Europe<ref>Jill Liddington, "What is Public History? Publics and Their Pasts, Meanings and Practices," ''Oral History'' (Spring 2002)</ref><ref>Anthony R. Sutcliffe, "Gleams and Echoes of Public History in Western Europe: Before and After the Rotterdam Conference," ''The Public Historian'' Vol. 6, No. 4 (Fall 1984), pp. 7-16</ref> and other places. In Latin America, public history finds its highest expression in Brazil, where public history is closely connected with social history and oral history. The Brazilian Public History Network, created in 2012, has been responsible for promoting publications and sponsoring events of national and international scope aimed to foster a creative and cosmopolitan dialogue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazilian Public History Network|url=http://www.historiapublica.com.br}}</ref> As in the U.S. and Canada, there are many public projects involving historians and the interpretation of history that do not necessarily claim the specific label “public history.” The International Federation for Public History,(IFPH-FIHP)<ref>[http://ifph.hypotheses.org International Federation for Public History - Fédération Internationale pour l'Histoire Publique]</ref> was formed in 2010 and became an international association with elected Steering Committee in January 2012.<ref>[http://ncph.org/cms/wp-content/uploads/PHN-2012-September1.pdf Serge Noiret: Next Steps for the International Federation, Public History News, Volume 32, Number 4, September 2012, p.10]</ref> IFPH is also a permanent <ref>[http://www.cish.org/EN/membres/internal-commissions.html#public Internal Commission for the International Committee of Historical Sciences] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923203723/http://www.cish.org/EN/membres/internal-commissions.html |date=2015-09-23 }}</ref> Internal Commission of the International Committee of Historical Sciences (ICHS-CISH). The IFPH seeks to broaden international exchanges about the practice and teaching of public history and it is one of the constitutive co-operation partners of the journal ''[[Public History Weekly]]''.
Public history continues to develop and define itself. There are currently many graduate and undergraduate public history programs in the U.S., Canada, and other countries (see list and links below). The field has a natural synergy with [[digital history]], with its emphasis on access and broad participation in the creation of historical knowledge. In recent years there has been a growing body of public historical scholarship, including works recognized by the annual [http://ncph.org/cms/?page_id=105 NCPH Book Award]. In several countries, studies have been conducted to explore how people understand and engage with the past, deepening public historians’ sense of how their own work can best connect with their audiences.<ref>For an overview of these, see Margaret Conrad, Jocelyn Létourneau, and David Northrup, "Canadians and Their Pasts: An Exploration in Historical Consciousness," ''The Public Historian'' Vol. 31, No. 1 (February 2009)</ref> While high-profile “history wars” have taken place over public exhibits and interpretations of history in many places in recent years (for example, [[History wars|Australia's]] ongoing debate over the history of colonisation and indigenous peoples, the furor over [[Jack Granatstein]]’s 1998 book “Who Killed Canadian History?”, or the 1994 controversy over the [[National Museum of American History]]'s planned exhibit on the [[Enola Gay#Recent developments|Enola Gay]] bomber), public historians tend to welcome these as opportunities to participate in vigorous public discussions over the meanings of the past, debating how people arrive at those meanings.
An evolving form of locally collected and publicly presented history, seen in projects like [[If This House Could Talk]] are a less critical and validated public presentation of history, yet offer engagement at the grass roots level that may encourage new forms of collecting history about the everyday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.preservationnation.org/forum/library/public-articles/iif-this-house-could.html |title= Connecting Neighbors through their buildings}}</ref>
==Examples==
The [[National Council on Public History]]'s Robert Kelley Memorial Award, “honors distinguished and outstanding achievements by individuals, institutions, non-profit or corporate entities for having made significant inroads in making history relevant to individual lives of ordinary people outside of academia.”<ref>[http://ncph.org/cms/?page_id=477 Robert Kelley Memorial Award]</ref> Its recipients reflect a broad mix of scholarly, governmental, and popular projects: * 2014 - Michael Devine, Director, [[Harry S. Truman Library and Museum]] * 2012 - Lindsey Reed, Managing Editor of [[The Public Historian]] * 2010 – Richard Allan Baker, United States Senate Historical Office * 2008 – Alan S. Newell, Historical Research Associates, Inc. * 2006 – Dwight T. Pitcaithley, National Park Service * 2004 – The Government and Citizens of the [[Tr’ondëk Hwëch’in First Nation|Tr’ondek Hwech’in]], First Native Peoples of the Klondike * 2002 – The University of South Carolina Public History Program * 2001 – Debra Bernhardt, Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University * 1999 – Otis L.Graham Jr., University of North Carolina, Wilmington * 1998 – The American Social History Project * 1997 – Page Putnam Miller, Coordinating Committee for the Promotion of History (now the National Coalition for History)
==University programs== An extensive listing of undergraduate and graduate programs in public history in the U.S., Canada, and elsewhere, are on the National Council on Public History website.
* MA in Public History (Heritage Interpretation or Historic Preservation) [http://www.semo.edu/history/academics/ma-public-history.html] Southeast Missouri State University * MA & PhD in Public History [[North Carolina State University]], Raleigh, NC, United States * MA in Public History [[West Virginia University]], Morgantown, WV United States * MA in Public History, [[University of South Carolina]], Columbia, SC * MA & Ph.D. in Public History, [[Arizona State University]], Tempe, Arizona, United States * MA in History with Concentration in Public History, [[American University]], Washington, D.C., United States * MA in History with Concentration in Public History, [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]], Amherst MA, United States *MA in Public Humanities, [[Brown University]], Providence, RI, United States * MA in History with Concentration in Public History, [[Georgia Southern University]], Statesboro GA, United States<ref>http://class.georgiasouthern.edu/history/home/public-history-program/</ref> * MA in Public History, [http://www.ccsu.edu/history/graduate/MA_publicHistory.html Central Connecticut State University], New Britain, Connecticut, United States * MA in Public History, [[Carleton University]], Ottawa, Ontario, Canada * MA in Public History, [[University of Houston]], Houston, Texas * MA in Public History, [[Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis]], Indiana, United States * MA in Public History & Joint PhD in American History/Public History, [[Loyola University Chicago]], Chicago, Illinois, United States * MA in Public History, The University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Massachusetts, United States * MA Public History, Department of History, [[Royal Holloway, University of London]] * MA in Public History, Oral History and Community Heritage, [[University of Huddersfield]], United Kingdom * MA Public History, [[Ruskin College]] Oxford * MA in Public History, [[Stephen F. Austin State University]], Nacogdcohes, Texas * MA in Public History, [[Temple University]], Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States * MA in Public History, [[Texas State University]], San Marcos, Texas, United States * MA & PhD in Public History, [[University of California, Santa Barbara]]; also has joint PhD program in Public History with California State University, Sacramento * [[The Public History Program at The University of Western Ontario#Public History in Canada|MA in Public History, The University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, Canada]] * MA in Public History, [[Wright State University]], Dayton, Ohio * MA in Public History and Cultural Heritage, [[Trinity College, Dublin]] * MA in Historical Studies, Public History Track, [[University of Maryland]], Baltimore County, Baltimore, MD, United States * MA & Ph.D. In Public History, [[Middle Tennessee State University]] * MA in Public History, [[Freie Universität Berlin]], Germany * MA & PhD in Public History, [[University of California, Riverside]] * MA in History with Concentration in Public History, [[North Dakota State University]], Fargo, North Dakota, United States * MA in History with a Public History Emphasis, [[University of Missouri-Kansas City]], Kansas City, Missouri, United States * MA in Applied (Public) and Interdisciplinary History "Usable Pasts", [https://spb.hse.ru/en/ma/apphist/ Higher School of Economics], St. Petersburg<nowiki>]</nowiki>] * MA in Public History, [[University of Amsterdam]], Amsterdam, The Netherlands * BA/BS in History with a Concentration in Public History, [[Ball State University]], Muncie, Indiana, United States * BA in History with an Emphasis in Public History, [[Grand Canyon University]], Phoenix, Arizona, United States<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gcu.edu/degree-programs/bachelor-arts-public-history|title=Bachelor of Arts in Public History {{!}} GCU|website=www.gcu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== * Andrew Hurley. ''Beyond Preservation: Using Public History to Revitalize Inner Cities'' (Temple University Press; 2010) 248 pages; focus on successful projects in St. Louis and other cities. * [http://ncph.org/cms/what-is-public-history/ What is Public History?] from the NCPH * [http://tph.ucpress.edu/content/11/3/69/ Reflections on an Idea: NCPH’s First Decade] by Barbara J. Howe, Chair's Annual Address, The Public Historian, Vol. 11, No. 3 (Summer 1989), pp. 69–85 * Public History in Canada. Special Issue, ''The Public Historian,'' Vol. 30, No. 1 (Winter 2009). * Juniele R. Almeida & Marta G. O. Rovai (ed.) ''Introdução à História Pública'' (Letra e Voz; 2011); first Brazilian public history handbook. * [https://www.academia.edu/881804/La_Public_History_una_disciplina_fantasma_Public_History_a_Ghost_Discipline_ La “Public History”: una disciplina fantasma?] in Serge Noiret (ed.): "Public History. Pratiche nazionali e identità globale", ''Memoria e Ricerca'', n.37, May–August 2011, pp. 10–35. (together with " Premessa: per una Federazione Internazionale di Public History", pp. 5–7.) * Serge Noiret. [https://public-history-weekly.degruyter.com/2-2014-34/internationalizing-public-history/ ''Internationalizing Public History''] in ''Public History Weekly'' Vol. 2, No. 34 (sept. 2014) * Irmgard Zündorf. [http://docupedia.de/zg/Zuendorf_public_history_v2_en_2017 ''Contemporary History and Public History''] in ''Docupedia Zeitgeschichte'', March 16, 2017.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Public History}} [[Category:Fields of history]] [[Category:Museology]] [[Category:Public sphere|History]]

'''Regional autonomy''' is [[decentralization]] of governance to outlying regions. Recent examples of disputes over '''autonomy''' include:
* The [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] region of Spain * The [[Catalonia|Catalan]] region of Spain * The disputes over autonomy of provinces in [[Indonesia]]. * The disputes over autonomy of region of [[Gilgit-Baltistan]]. * The disputes over autonomy of provinces in [[Sri Lanka]].
Current examples of autonomous regions include the [[Guangxi]] Zhuang [[Autonomous regions of China|Autonomous Region]] in China and the [[Cherokee Nation]] in the United States.
==External links== *[http://www.idea.int/publications/country/upload/6_regional_autonomy.pdf Regional Autonomy in Indonesia: How to Make Decentralization Work]
[[Category:Politics]] [[Category:Autonomy]] [[Category:Decentralization]]
{{poli-stub}}

page.title: Revue et gazette musicale de Paris

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:Cover of 'Revue et Gazette musicale de Paris' 1835 vol2 n46 - Internet Archive.jpg|thumb|Cover of ''Revue et Gazette Musicale de Paris'' (15 November 1835)]]
The '''''{{Lang|fr|Revue musicale}}''''' was a weekly musical review founded in 1827 by the Belgian [[musicologist]], teacher and composer [[François-Joseph Fétis]], then working as professor of [[counterpoint]] and [[fugue]] at the [[Conservatoire de Paris]]. It was the first French-language journal dedicated entirely to classical music. In November 1835 it merged with [[Maurice Schlesinger]]'s '''''Gazette musicale de Paris''''' (first published in January 1834) to form '''''Revue et gazette musicale de Paris''''', first published on 1 November 1835. It ceased publication in 1880.
==History== By 1830 the '''''Revue musicale''''', written and published by Fétis, was on sale at [[Maurice Schlesinger]]'s music seller's premises.<ref name="RF_13-14">Vol 7 (Tome VIII, IV<sup>me</sup> année) (1830) sold by Fétis, Alexandre Mesnier & Schlesinger. See review of Vol. 7 in [https://books.google.com/books?id=WtsnAQAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA281 ''Revue française'', Issues 13-14, p. 281-3].</ref> Schlesinger (whose father founded the ''Berliner allgemeine musikalische Zeitung'') was a German music editor who had moved to Paris in 1821. Schlesinger published editions of classical and modern music under his own name at a reasonable price, most notably works by [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]], [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber]], [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], [[Johann Nepomuk Hummel|Hummel]] and [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]. He also published ''[[Robert le diable]]''<ref>Full score of Schlesinger's edition of [http://imslp.org/wiki/Robert_le_diable_%28Meyerbeer,_Giacomo%29 Robert le diable] at IMSLP.</ref> and ''[[Les Huguenots]]'' by [[Giacomo Meyerbeer]], as well as ''[[La Juive]]'' by [[Fromental Halévy]].<ref>{{Fr icon}} ''{{Lang|fr|Larousse encyclopédique}}'' vol. 9, p. 9405.</ref> Schlesinger founded his own rival publication, the '''''Gazette Musicale de Paris''''', which first appeared on 5 January 1834.<ref>{{Fr icon}} {{cite book |title=Gazette Musicale de Paris |volume=I<sup>re</sup> année, No. 1 |date=5 January 1834 |others= [[Maurice Schlesinger|Schlesinger, Maurice]] (ed.) |url=https://archive.org/stream/gazettemusicaled18341pari#page/n5/mode/2up}}</ref><ref>{{Fr icon}} ''{{Lang|fr|Dictionnaire de la musique}}'' Larousse, p. 286 {{ISBN|978-2-03-505545-3}}.</ref>
Another music journal, ''[[Le Ménestrel]]'', had first appeared the previous month on 1 December 1833.<ref>{{cite book |ref={{harvid|Le Ménestrel|1883-4|}} |title=Le Ménestrel |date=1 December 1833 |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5619191p/f8 |issue=Année 1, No. 0 |language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |authorlink=Théophile Gautier |last=Gautier |first=Théophile |year=1995 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QHd3nF0cAbEC&pg=PA156&dq=Le+M%C3%A9nestrel+%22L'Henry%22&hl=en#v=snippet&q=L'Henry&f=false |title=Correspondance générale 1865–1867 |editor1-first= Claudine |editor1-last=Lacoste-Veysseyre |publisher=Librairie Droz |isbn=2-600-00075-5 |language=French}}</ref> Until ''La Revue et Gazette'' ceased publication in 1880, ''Le Ménestrel'' was to be its main rival in terms of influence and breadth of coverage.<ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Ellis |first= Katharine |year=2007 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7LC3WSReyLQC&pg=PA2&dq=%22Le+M%C3%A9nestrel%22+Heugel&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22Le%20M%C3%A9nestrel%22%20Heugel |title=Music Criticism in Nineteenth-Century France |page=2 |publisher= Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-521-03589-9}}</ref>
In 1835, Schlesinger bought the ''Revue musicale'' from Fétis and merged the two journals into the '''''Revue et gazette musicale de Paris'''''. He widened the subject matter of the ''{{Lang|fr|Gazette musicale}}'' from music itself to also include literature about music – in 1837 he commissioned from [[Honoré de Balzac]] for the ''Gazette'' the [[novella]] ''[[Gambara (short story)|Gambara]]'' (dealing with the new style of [[grand opera]]).<ref>{{Fr icon}} René Guise, ''La Pléiade'', p. 1517. Pierre Brunel, "{{Lang|fr|Histoire du texte}}", ''Folio Classique'', 1995, pp. 318–9 comprising ''Gambara'', ''[[Sarrasine]]'', ''[[Massimilla Doni]]''.</ref>
The name ''Revue musicale'' returned for six months in 1839 as the '''''Revue musicale, journal des artistes, des amateurs et des théatres''''' while the journal was a bi-weekly publication. The list of contributors to the ''Revue et gazette musicale'' in 1840 included: [[François Benoist]], [[Hector Berlioz]], [[Castil-Blaze]], [[Antoine Elwart]], [[Stephen Heller]], [[Jules Janin]], [[Jean-Georges Kastner]], [[Franz Liszt]], [[Édouard Monnais]] (director of the [[Paris Opera]] from 1839 to 1847), [[Joseph d'Ortigue]], [[Theodor Panofka]], [[Ludwig Rellstab]], [[Georges Sand]], [[Robert Schumann]], and one [[Richard Wagner]].
==Publication chronology, 1827—1850== ;''Revue musicale'' Published by Fétis. First series (6 volumes): *[https://books.google.com/books?id=9k5DAAAAcAAJ Vol. 1 (1827)] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=_1hDAAAAcAAJ Vol. 2 (1828)] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=WMEPAAAAYAAJ Vol. 3 (1828)] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=ojUuAAAAYAAJ Vol. 4 (1829)] <!-- or [https://archive.org/details/revuemusicale1829pari] --> *[https://books.google.com/books?id=_C4uAAAAYAAJ Vol. 5 (1829)] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=gSZDAAAAcAAJ Vol. 6 (1830)] (published early 1830)<ref>Page 625 of Vol. 6 contains an announcement of a new series of the journal to incorporate serious analysis of new compositions, along with improved technology for printing musical examples ("les perfectionnemens de fabrication thypographique")<!--sic-->. The new series begins on 6 Feb 1830. Vol. 6 also contains a cumulative index of the first 6 volumes.</ref> Second series (14 volumes): * [https://archive.org/details/revuemusicale18307pari Vol. 1] (Tome premier), 1st issue 6 February 1830 <!-- or https://books.google.com/books?id=gSZDAAAAcAAJ --> *[https://archive.org/details/revuemusicale18308pari Vol. 2] (Tome second) (pub. 1830) *[https://archive.org/details/revuemusicale18309pari Vol. 3] (Tome troisième) (1830) * ''Vols. 4-5'' (1830) *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k69764j/f7.image Vol. 6] (Tome VI, quatrième année) (1830) * ''Vol. 7'' (1830) (Tome VIII, IV<sup>me</sup> année) <ref name="RF_13-14" /> * ''Vols. 8-10'' (1830)<ref>[https://www.schubertiademusic.com/items/details/3153-fetis-francoisjoseph-revue-musicale-deuxi%C3%A8me-s%C3%A9rie-quatri%C3%A8me-ann%C3%A9e-tome-x-e-livraison Quatrième année, Tome X]. Cover photo and publication details, retrieved 19 October 2015.</ref> *[https://archive.org/details/revuemusicale1831pari Vol. 11] (pub. 1832) (Tome XI - V<sup>me</sup> année - 1831) Published on Saturdays from at least January 1831 (Vol. 11). *[https://archive.org/details/revuemusicale1832pari Vol. 12] (pub. 1832) (Tome XII - VI<sup>me</sup> année- 1832) * ''Vol. 13'' (1833) (Tome XIII)<ref>See note in Bindseil, H. E. (1839) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ln05AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA68 ''Akustik''] (in German), p. 68</ref> * ''Vol. 14'' (January 1834) (Tome XIV)<ref>See note in Fétis, F-J, [https://books.google.com/books?id=eMs9AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA460 ''Biographie universelle des musiciens...'', Volume 4] (in French), p. 460</ref>
;''Gazette musicale de Paris'' Published by Schlesinger, appeared on Sundays. * [https://archive.org/stream/gazettemusicaled18341pari#page/n5/mode/2up 1834, Vol. 1] (First edition, 1<sup>ère</sup> année, No. 1, Sunday 5 January 1834) * [https://archive.org/details/gazettemusicaled18342pari 1834, Vol. 2] (1<sup>ère</sup> année, No. 27, 6 July 1834) * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ee8qAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA353 1835, Vol. 1] (2<sup>e</sup> année, No. 2, 11 January 1835). In issue 44, pp. 353–4 (the first edition of ''Revue et Gazette Musicale de Paris'') Schlesinger - comparing himself to a general of Ancient Greece - announced on 1 November 1835 in glowing terms that the struggle with Fétis had been won, and that ''La Revue Musicale'' would pass, with arms and baggage-train, ensigns flying and with all the honours of war, into the ''Gazette musicale''.<ref>"''La Revue Musicale'' passe,<!--"Tout lasse, tout passe"--> avec armes et baggages, enseignes déployés et tous les honneurs de la guerre, a la ''Gazette musicale''".</ref> Fétis announced that subscribers to his ''Revue'' would receive the Gazette under the Revue's masthead until 1 January 1836, and that he would continue to write exclusively for the Gazette. * [https://archive.org/stream/revueetgazettemu4552pari#page/n63/mode/2up 1835, Vol. 2] (Nos. 45-52, November–December 1835, with supplements) ; ''Revue et gazette musicale de Paris'' Appeared on Sundays. *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu18363pari 3rd year, 1836] *[https://archive.org/stream/revueetgazettemu18374pari#page/n3/mode/2up 4th year, 1837] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=te0qAAAAYAAJ 5th year, 1838] * 6th year, 1839. From January 1839 until 11 April 1841 the journal appeared twice weekly, on Thursdays and Sundays. For the first six months, (January–June 1839), the Thursday edition appeared as **'''''Revue musicale, journal des artistes, des amateurs et des théatres''''' with similar font and masthead design. The first edition appeared on Thursday 3 January 1839, with consistent volume numbering, as 6<sup>e</sup> année, No. 1.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Revue musicale, journal des artistes, des amateurs et des théatres |title=Masthead |date=3 January 1839 |volume=6 |issue=1 |page=1 |url=https://archive.org/stream/revueetgazettemu1839pari#page/8/mode/2up}}</ref> The Sunday edition continued as **[https://archive.org/stream/revueetgazettemu18396pari#page/n3/mode/2up ''Revue et gazette musicale de Paris'', 6th year, 1839] (6<sup>e</sup> année, No. 1). NB The date of the first issue is misprinted 6 Janvier ''1838'' instead of 1839. *[https://archive.org/stream/revueetgazettemu18407pari#page/n7/mode/2up 7th year, 1840] (bi-weekly) *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu18418pari 8th year, 1841] (bi-weekly until issue of 11 April 1841, p. 225, then Sundays only from 18 April) *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu18429pari 9th year, 1842] *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu1843pari 10th year, 1843] * [https://archive.org/stream/revueetgazettemu1844pari#page/8/mode/2up 1844] Changes to masthead design and layout. (supplement to 7 January issue contains facsimiles of hundreds of signatures of composers and musicians). *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu1845pari 1845] *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu1846pari 1846] Schlesinger sold the journal in 1846 to a former employee, Louis Brandus. *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu1847pari 1847] Reverts to old masthead & layout. *[https://books.google.com/books?id=oLlCAAAAcAAJ 1848] (Google books) *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu1849pari 1849] *[https://archive.org/details/revueetgazettemu1850pari 1850] *etc. until 1880 The journal was suspended from September 1870 to September 1871 during the [[Siege of Paris (1870–71)|Siege of Paris]], bringing the [[Franco-Prussian War]] to an end.

{{Infobox scientist | name = Ruth Gates | birth_name = Ruth Deborah Gates | birth_date = {{Birth date|1962|3|28|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia|Akrotiri]], Cyprus | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|10|25|1962|3|28|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Kailua,_Honolulu_County,_Hawaii|Kailua]], Hawaii, U.S. | workplaces = [[University of California, Los Angeles]]
[[Hawai'i Institute of Marine Biology]] | alma_mater = [[Newcastle University]] (BSc, PhD) | thesis_title = Seawater temperature and algal-cnidarian symbiosis | thesis_url = https://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?uin=uk.bl.ethos.346445 | thesis_year = 1989 | spouse = Robin Burton-Gates | known_for = [[Coral reef]] research | field = [[Marine biology]] | website = {{URL|gatescorallab.com}} }} '''Ruth Deborah Gates''' (March 28, 1962 – October 25, 2018) was the Director of the [[Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology]] and the first woman to be President of the [[International Society for Reef Studies]]. Her research was dedicated to understanding [[coral reef]] ecosystems, specifically coral-algal symbiosis and the capacity for corals to acclimatize under future [[climate change]] conditions.{{Google scholar id}} == Education == Gates was inspired by the documentary ''[[The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/04/18/a-radical-attempt-to-save-the-reefs-and-forests|title=A Radical Attempt to Save the Reefs and Forests|work=The New Yorker|last=Kolbert|first=Elizabeth|date=2016-04-18|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} She studied biology at [[Newcastle University]] where she earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in 1984.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/ruth-gates|title=Ruth Gates|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} She fell in love with corals during a diving trip to the [[West Indies]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.hawaiibusiness.com/20-for-the-next-20-2016/|title=20 for the Next 20: 2016|date=2016-03-03|work=Hawaii Business Magazine|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} In 1985 she moved to the [[West Indies]] to study corals. She completed her [[PhD]] at [[Newcastle University]] in 1989 on seawater temperature and [[algal]]-[[cnidaria]]n [[symbiosis]].{{cite thesis|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Newcastle upon Tyne|url=https://copac.jisc.ac.uk/id/18918380?style=html|title=Seawater temperature and algal-cnidarian symbiosis|first= Ruth Deborah|last=Gates|date=1989|id={{EThOS|uk.bl.ethos.346445}}|website=jisc.ac.uk|oclc=557254204}} ==Career and research== After her PhD, Gates was appointed a [[postdoctoral researcher]] at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. She spent thirteen years working as a junior researcher in California. She was there during the 1998 [[bleaching event]] that killed more than 15 % of corals across the world. Gates joined the [[Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology]] 2003.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tetiaroasociety.org/ruth-gates|title=Ruth Gates {{!}} Tetiaroa Society|website=www.tetiaroasociety.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} She studied corals and reefs, learning how they function and working on ways to slow their decline. She worked on [[Coconut Island]], trying to identify why some corals survive bleaching.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2012/03/corals-ocean-temperature/|title=Some Corals May Adapt to Warming Seas|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} Her group monitored the ecosystems of coral reefs to understand how a changing environment impacted coral health.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/monitoring-reefs|title=Monitoring Reefs|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} The corals in shallow patches like [[Kāneʻohe Bay]] are subject to high temperatures and irradiance. Alongside seawater temperature, they measure photosynthetic active radiation, salinity and nutrient composition. This allowed them to build [[3D modeling|3D models]] of reefs.{{Citation|last=TheJohnburns84|title=Ke'ei|date=2015-10-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TxZLu7wByKY&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-10-28}} They study the [[symbiodinium]] that live within coral tissues. These provide the corals with energy and are lost during coral bleaching.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/symbiodinium-and-symbioses|title=Symbiodinium and Symbioses|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} They develop new techniques for data analysis and management, including developing EarthCube and CRESCYNT.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/data-management-and-analysis|title=Data Management and Analysis|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1440342|title=NSF Award Search: Award#1440342 - Earthcube RCN: Coral REef Science & CYberinfrastructure NeTwork (CReSCyNT)|website=www.nsf.gov|access-date=2018-10-28}} Gates was concerned about [[sunscreen]] that contains [[octinoxate]] and [[oxybenzone]], and in 2015 called for it to be banned in Hawaii.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/clip/11941033/that-sunscreen-you-slather-on-it-might-be-damaging-coral|title=That sunscreen you slather on? It might be damaging coral|last=|first=|date=|website=Hawaii News Now|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-28}} These sunscreens were banned in 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-05-04/hawaii-bans-sunscreen-coral-bleaching/9728322|title=Would you change sunscreen if it could help save the Great Barrier Reef?|date=2018-05-04|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-AU}} In 2012 she demonstrated that the choice of symbiotic algae was crucial for how tropical reefs survived environmental stresses.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=125278&org=NSF|title=Tropical Reefs Surviving Environmental Stresses: Corals' Choice of Symbiotic Algae May Hold the Key {{!}} NSF - National Science Foundation|website=www.nsf.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=https://app.dimensions.ai/details/grant/grant.2996203|title=A comprehensive survey of endosymbiotic and free-living Symbiodinium diversity in the corals and reef environments of Hawaii - Dimensions|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} She predicted that more than 90 percent of the world's corals will be dead by 2050.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/environment-90-percent-coral-reefs-die-2050-climate-change-bleaching-pollution-a7626911.html|title=More than 90 percent of coral reefs will die out by 2050|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}} === Super coral === In 2013, she won the [[Paul G. Allen]] Ocean Challenge, a $10,000 prize that allowed her to improve the resilience of vulnerable coral reef ecosystems.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pgaphilanthropies.org/oceanchallenge/|title=OceanChallenge - Home|website=www.pgaphilanthropies.org|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.pgaphilanthropies.org/news/news-articles/press-releases/press-release-the-paul-g-allen-family-foundation-n|title=Press Release - The Paul G. Allen Family Foundation Names Winner of Inaugural Ocean Challenge - Paul G. Allen Philanthropies|website=www.pgaphilanthropies.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} For the proposal, Gates joined [[Madeleine van Oppen]], and used genetic selection to boost resilience to environmental stress.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aims.gov.au/docs/media/latest-releases/-/asset_publisher/8Kfw/content/ocean-prize-for-assisted-coral-evolution|title=About the Australian Institute of Marine Science|author=Anon|website=www.aims.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} They did this by exposing cross-bred corals to successively warmer and more acidic experimental tanks.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/climate/coral-great-barrier-reef.html|title=Building a Better Coral Reef|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/environment/this-coral-must-die/|title=This coral must die|date=2018-07-06|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/hawaiian-coral-evolution-sparks-worldwide-debate|title=Hawaiian coral evolution sparks worldwide debate|date=2016-02-13|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/05/scientists-can-engineer-climate-resistant-coral/|title=The Controversial Race to Breed Climate-Adapted Super Coral|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} She was awarded the [[University of Hawaii]] Board of Regents Medal for Excellence in Research.{{Cite web|url=https://www.hawaii.edu/about/awards/research.php|title=Regents' Medal for Excellence in Research :: University of Hawaii System|last=System|first=University of Hawaii|website=www.hawaii.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} ''Coral Assisted Evolution, a'' $4 million research project, was funded by the [[Paul G. Allen Frontiers Group]].{{Cite web|url=http://coralassistedevolution.com/contact|title=Contact|website=coralassistedevolution.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} This supported Gates' research for four years from 2016, developing ''super corals'' that can withstand climate change.{{Citation|last=Vulcan Inc.|title=Innovator Profiles: Ruth Gates Is Working to Save Coral Reefs|date=2018-02-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmxUXLb539o&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-10-28}} Whilst Gates was concerned about playing with nature, she could not sit by and watch species become extinct without acting.{{Cite news|url=https://www.yaleclimateconnections.org/2016/06/horrifying-research-seeks-to-save-hawaii-coral-reefs/|title='Horrifying' research seeks to save Hawaii reefs » Yale Climate Connections|date=2016-06-28|work=Yale Climate Connections|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} In 2016, Gates was named by [[Hawaii Business]] as one of the top 20 leaders of Hawaii. She explored whether non-super corals could be encouraged to take on new symbionts to improve their ability to withstand high temperatures. If Gates' project is successful, it could save the US $9.9 trillion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/business/article/2149588/saving-worlds-coral-avert-wipeout-irreversible-costs|title=Saving the world’s coral to avert a wipeout of irreversible costs|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} In 2018, the foundation supported a coral reef map, that allowed scientists to monitor corals in unprecedented detail.{{Cite web|url=https://www.planet.com/pulse/planet-paul-g-allen-coral-map/|title=Planet, Paul G. Allen Philanthropies, & Leading Scientists Team Up to Map & Monitor World’s Corals in Unprecedented Detail|website=www.planet.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} === Public engagement === She was elected the president of the [[International Society for Reef Studies]].{{Cite web|url=http://coralreefs.org/society-organisation/officers-and-members-of-council/|title=Officers & Councilors – International Society for Reef Studies|website=coralreefs.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-28}} The ''Super Coral'' proposals were featured in ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'', [[Gizmodo]], [[PBS]], ''[[Newsweek]]'', ''[[Hawaii Business]]'', ''[[National Geographic]]'', the ''[[Huffington post]]'', ''[[New Scientist]]'' and the [[BBC]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030680-600-im-creating-supercharged-corals-to-beat-climate-change/|title=I’m creating supercharged corals to beat climate change|last=Schiffman|first=Richard|work=New Scientist|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90188094/scientists-are-speeding-up-evolution-to-build-climate-change-resistance|title=Scientists are speeding up evolution to build climate change resistance|date=2018-07-18|website=fastcompany.com|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://oceantoday.noaa.gov/fullmoon-scienceofsupercorals/welcome.html|title=The Science of Super Corals - Coral Comeback|website=oceantoday.noaa.gov|language=EN-US|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/super-coral-reefs-climate-change-462172|title=Climate-adapted “super coral” could help revive the world's ailing reefs|date=2016-05-22|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}{{Citation|title=Super Coral That Can Survive Global Warming|url=http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/news/160323-breeding-super-coral-vin?source=relatedvideo|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20160322-the-women-with-a-controversial-plan-to-save-corals|title=The women with a controversial plan to save corals|last=Riley|first=Alex|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hawaiibusiness.com/hawaiis-super-coral/|title=Hawaii’s Super Coral: Evolution on Fast Forward|date=2018-09-12|work=Hawaii Business Magazine|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} Her work was featured on the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Chasing Coral]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.netflix.com/title/80168188|title=Chasing Coral {{!}} Netflix Official Site|website=www.netflix.com|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.chasingcoral.com/the-team/|title=Team - Chasing Coral|work=Chasing Coral|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencefriday.com/segments/chasing-coral-movie/|title=In The Story Of Dying Coral Reefs, A Call To Action|work=Science Friday|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}She was an invited speaker at the 2017 [[Aspen Ideas Festival]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.aspenideas.org/speaker/ruth-gates|title=Ruth Gates {{!}} Aspen Ideas Festival|website=Aspen Ideas Festival|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} She was featured on the University of Hawai'i Foundation video series in 2018.{{Citation|last=UH Foundation|title=Making a Marine Biologist - Ruth Gates Series|date=2018-02-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZVdAHjRzv8Q&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Citation|last=UH Foundation|title=Adapt or Die - Ruth Gates Series|date=2018-02-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pSjXQud_174|access-date=2018-10-28}} The Gates lab are involved with a wide range of public engagement and outreach, including hosting students from [[Mo'orea]].{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/international-impacts|title=International Impacts|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} She was a member of the [[Tetiaroa]] Society. ==Personal life == Gates was born in Cyprus, the sister of Timothy Gates. Her wife was Robin Burton-Gates. She died from [[brain cancer]] at 56 years old, just five months after its diagnosis.[https://www.civilbeat.org/2018/10/rip-ruth-gates-the-world-loses-a-top-coral-scientist-and-indomitable-spirit/ RIP Ruth Gates: The World Loses A Top Coral Scientist And ‘Indomitable Spirit’], ''[[Honolulu Civil Beat]]'', October 30, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2018/10/optimist-who-believed-saving-corals/574240/|title=The Fight for Corals Loses Its Great Champion|last=Yong|first=Ed||work=The Atlantic|date=2018-10-29|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} == References == {{Authority control}} [[Category:English biologists]] [[Category:Alumni of Newcastle University]] [[Category:University of Hawaii faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:Environmental scientists]] [[Category:2018 deaths]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2007}}
A '''sliding door operator''' (or '''sliding door opener''' or '''automatic sliding door operator''') is a device that operates a [[sliding door]] for pedestrian use. It opens the door automatically, waits, then closes it. [[File:Oorlogsmuseum Overloon.JPG|thumb|Sliding door with opener in a museum]]
== Uses == Sliding door operators are typically used on the outside doors of large retail businesses. (smaller retail businesses prefer [[swing door operator]]s.) They are also used in [[elevator|elevators (lifts)]]
== Triggering == A door operator may be triggered in various ways: * Approach Sensor (such as a [[radar sensor]]) - the door opens when a user approaches it. * Pushbutton - the door opens when a user presses a button. * Access control - the door opens when an [[Access control|Access Control System]] determines the user is authorized to go through. * Automatically (in the case of elevators) A trigger from any of the above requests that the door be opened (or reopened if it was closing).
== Safety sensors == Sensors can be used to detect obstacles in the path of closing doors. The simplest sensor consists of a light beam aimed across the opening: when the beam is broken by an obstacle, the operator prevents the door from closing. [[Infrared]] and [[radar]] safety sensors are also commonly used.
Other sensors such as resistance-sensing motors can be used to reverse the closing action of the door after an obstacle is encountered.
==Technology== The operator is placed in the space above the sliding door.
An [[electric motor]], geared down to get a lower speed and a higher [[torque]], drives a [[pulley]] at one end of a belt. The door is clamped to the belt. To open the door, the motor turns the pulley, which in turn turns the belt, which in turn drags the door. To close the door, the reverse occurs.
Historically, elevator doors were opened by a set of mechanical linkages; the motor, geared down, would rotate linked arms, which in turn would drive the door.
==Types== There are several types of sliding doors, these are:
* Standard sliding door (single wing or double wings) * Telescopic sliding door (two wings or four wings) * Circular sliding door (segment circular, semi-circular or full circular) * Sliding folding door (two wings or four wings) * Hermetic sliding door (single wing or double wings) * All glass sliding door (single wing or double wings) * [[Clean room]] sliding door (single wing or double wings)
== External links == *Overview of ANSI standards [http://www.edsdoors.com/ansi_156_10.htm] *[http://circuitdigest.com/microcontroller-projects/automatic-door-opener-project-using-arduino PIR Sensor based Automatic Door Opener Project] [[Category:Electromechanical engineering]] [[Category:Automation]] [[Category:Doors]]

{{Infobox Organization | name = Société Chimique de France | image = SCF France logo.jpg | image_border = | size = 200 px | caption = | formation = 1857 | type = [[Learned society]] | headquarters = [[Paris]] | location = France | membership = | language = French | leader_title = | leader_name = | key_people = | num_staff = | budget = | website = www.societechimiquedefrance.fr }}
The '''Société Chimique de France''' ('''SCF''') is a [[learned society]] and [[professional association]] founded in 1857 to represent the interests of French chemists in a variety of ways in local, national and international contexts.<ref>Société Chimique de France (SCF), [http://www.societechimiquedefrance.fr/fr/missions-de-la-scf.html Mission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409094637/http://www.societechimiquedefrance.fr/fr/missions-de-la-scf.html |date=2010-04-09 }}; retrieved 2011-06-08.</ref> Until 2009 the organization was known as the '''Société Française de Chimie'''.
==History== The Society traces its origins back to an organization of young Parisian chemists who began meeting in May 1857 under the name Société Chimique, with the goal of self-study and mutual education. In 1858 the established chemist [[Adolphe Wurtz]] joined the society, and immediately transformed it into a [[learned society]] modeled after the [[Chemical Society]] of London, which was the precursor of the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]]. Like its British counterpart, the French association sought to foster the communication of new ideas and facts throughout France and across international borders.<ref name="Lagowski1991">Lagowski, J. J. (1991). [http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1021/ed068p1 "A British Sesquicentennial,"] ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' Vol 68, No. 1, p. 1; acknowledging the sesquicentennial of The Chemical Society in London, which eventually became the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]]; retrieved 2011-06-08.</ref>
==Activities== Support for the ''[[Bulletin de la Société Chimique de France|Bulletin de la Société Chimique de Paris]]'' began in 1858.
In the 21st century, the society has become a member of [[ChemPubSoc Europ]]e, which is an organization of 16 European chemical societies. This European consortium was established in the late 1990s as many chemical journals owned by national chemical societies were amalgamated.<ref>ChemPubSoc Europe, [http://www.wiley-vch.de/vch/journals/2111/chempubsoc-eu.html mission]; [http://www.wiley-vch.de/vch/journals/2111/chempubsoc-eu_members.html participating societies]</ref> In 2010 they started [[ChemistryViews]].org, their news and information service for chemists and other scientists worldwide.
===Prizes and awards=== The society acknowledges individual achievement with prizes and awards, including: * Louis Ancel Prize * Raymond Berr Prize :* 1978: [[Jean-Marie Lehn]]<ref name="jean-marie_lehn">Canal-U: [https://archive.is/20130119034824/http://www.canal-u.com/producteurs/universite_de_tous_les_savoirs/dossier_programmes/les_conferences_de_l_annee_2000/la_chimie_science_des_transformations/chimie_et_creation_du_moleculaire_au_supramoleculaire "Chimie et création. Du moléculaire au supramoléculaire" — Auteurs, Jean-Marie Lehn]</ref>
* [[Lavoisier Medal]] of the Société Chimique de France is awarded to a person or institution in order to distinguish the work or actions which have enhanced the perceived value of chemistry in society.<ref name="lavoisier_laureats">SCF, [http://www.societechimiquedefrance.fr/fr/la-medaille-lavoisier.html Lauréats de la médaille Lavoisier] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905044742/http://www.societechimiquedefrance.fr/fr/la-medaille-lavoisier.html |date=2010-09-05 }}</ref> :* 1904: [[James Dewar]] :* 1906: [[William Perkin]]<ref>[http://www.colorantshistory.org/home.html Colorants Industry History], [http://www.colorantshistory.org/PerkinBiography.html William H. Perkin]</ref> <!-- :* 1907: :* 1908: :* 1909: :* 1910: :* 1911: --> :* 1912: [[Victor Grignard]]<ref>Nobel Prize in Chemistry, 1912, [http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1912/grignard-bio.html Victor Grignard bio notes]</ref> <!-- :* 1913: :* 1914: :* 1915: :* 1916: :* 1917: :* 1918: :* 1919: :* 1920: :* 1921: --> :* 1922: [[Theodore William Richards]]<ref>Nobel Prize in Chemistry, 1914, [http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1914/richards-bio.html Theodore Richards bio notes]</ref> <!-- :* 1923: :* 1924: :* 1925: :* 1926: :* 1927: :* 1928: :* 1929: :* 1930: :* 1931: :* 1932: :* 1933: :* 1934: --> :* 1935: [[Cyril Norman Hinshelwood]]<ref>Nobel Prize in Chemistry, 1956: [https://web.archive.org/web/20110703034155/http://130.242.18.21/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1956/hinshelwood-bio.html Cyril Hinshelwood bio notes]</ref> <!-- :* 1936: :* 1937: :* 1938: :* 1939: :* 1940: :* 1941: :* 1942: :* 1943: :* 1944: :* 1945: :* 1946: :* 1947: --> :* 1948: [[Alexander R.
